sentence-detokenized: The EU rejects Germany's call for a boycott of British lamb.
Peter Blackburn
BRUSSELS 1996-08-22
The European Commission said on Thursday that it disagrees with German advice to consumers to avoid British lamb until scientists have established whether mad cow disease can be transmitted to sheep.

Werner Zwingmann, Germany's representative on the European Union's veterinary committee, said on Wednesday that consumers should buy sheep meat from countries other than the UK until scientific advice is clearer.
"We do not support such a recommendation because we do not see the reasons for it," said the Commission's chief spokesman, Nikolaus van der Pas, at a press conference.
He said that further scientific study was needed and that the European Union should act if it found it necessary.

He said that last month's proposal by the European Commissioner for Agriculture, Franz Fischler, to ban sheep brain, spleen and spinal cord from the human and animal food chain was a very specific and precautionary move to protect human health.
Fischler proposed EU-level action following reports from the UK and France that sheep can be infected with BSE - mad cow disease - in laboratory conditions.

However, Fischler agreed to revise his proposal after the EU's Standing Veterinary Committee and national animal health officials questioned whether such a measure was justified as there was only a small risk to human health.
At a meeting of EU agriculture ministers, Spanish Agriculture Minister Loyola de Palacio accused Fischler of causing unjustified alarm by making "dangerous generalisations".
Only France and the UK supported Fischler's proposal.
The EU's veterinary scientific and multidisciplinary committees are expected to review the issue early next month and make recommendations to senior veterinary officials.
Sheep have long been known to suffer from scrapie, a brain-destroying disease similar to BSE, which is thought to be transmitted to cattle through feed containing animal waste.

British farmers on Thursday denied that their sheep pose a risk to human health, but expressed concern that the German government's advice to consumers to avoid British lamb could affect consumers across Europe.
"We need to be extremely careful about how other countries model themselves on Germany," John Lloyd Jones, President of the Welsh National Farmers' Union (NFU), told BBC Radio.

Bonn has led efforts to protect public health after consumer confidence plummeted in March when a British report showed that people could contract a disease similar to mad cow disease if they ate contaminated beef.
Germany imported 47,600 sheep from the UK last year, almost half of the total.
It brought in 4 275 tonnes of British mutton, around 10% of total imports.
A rare draft of a Hendrix song sells for almost 17,000 dollars.
A rare early handwritten draft of a song by American guitar legend Jimi Hendrix sold for nearly $17,000 on Thursday at an auction of some of the late musician's favourite items.
A restaurant in Florida paid £10,925 ($16,935) for a draft of "Ain't no telling", which Hendrix wrote on stationery in a London hotel at the end of 1966.
At the end of a concert in Nottingham, England, in January 1967, he threw a piece of paper into the audience, where it was picked up by a fan.
The buyers also bought 16 other items auctioned by Hendrix's ex-girlfriend Kathy Etchingham, who lived with Hendrix between 1966 and 1969.
Among them was a black lacquer and pearl box used by Hendrix to store his drugs, bought by an anonymous Australian buyer for £5 060 ($7 845).
The guitarist died of a drug overdose in 1970, aged 27.
China says Taiwan is spoiling the atmosphere for talks.
BEIJING 1996-08-22
China on Thursday accused Taipei of spoiling the atmosphere for renewed cross-Strait talks with Taiwanese Vice President Lien Chan's visit to Ukraine this week, which angered Beijing.

Just hours after Chinese state media reported that it was time for political talks with Taiwan, Foreign Ministry spokesman Shen Guofang told Reuters that it was time for political talks. "The Taiwanese authorities have disturbed the necessary atmosphere for the start of the talks.
State media quoted China's chief negotiator with Taipei, Tang Shubei, as saying on Wednesday during a visit to Taiwan that it was time for the two rivals to start political talks.
"Now is the time for political talks between the two sides...
is to end the state of hostility," Tang was quoted as saying in Thursday's overseas edition of the People's Daily.

Speaking to Reuters, Shen of the foreign ministry said he had read reports on Tang's remarks, but gave no details on why the negotiator thought it was time to talk to Taiwan, which Beijing regards as a renegade province.
China, which has long opposed all Taipei's efforts for greater international recognition, was angered by Taiwanese Vice President Lien's visit to Ukraine this week.
China says it is the right time to talk about Taiwan.
BEIJING 1996-08-22
China has said that it is time for political talks with Taiwan and that the rival island should take practical steps to achieve this goal.

The official Xinhua news agency quoted Tang Shubei, executive vice-president of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait, as saying late on Wednesday evening that the timing and format of the talks should be discussed.
July car registrations in Germany up 14.2 percent year-on-year.
FRANKFURT 1996-08-22
According to the Federal Motor Vehicle Office, the number of motor vehicles registered for the first time in Germany increased by 14.2% in July this year compared to a year earlier.
According to the Bureau, 356,725 new cars were registered in July 1996 - 304,850 cars and 15,613 trucks.
Compared to July 1995, the number of passenger cars increased by 13.6% and the number of trucks decreased by 2.2%.
The number of registered motorcycles increased by 32.7% over the period.
The growth was partly due to more Germans buying German cars abroad, while manufacturers argued that domestic demand was weak, the Federal Office said.
Almost all German car manufacturers recorded an increase in registrations during the period.
Volkswagen AG gained 77,719 registrations, just over a quarter of all registrations.
Opel AG was joint second with General Motors with 49,269 registrations, 16.4% of the total.
Ford came third with 35,563 registrations, or 11.7%.
Only Seat and Porsche had fewer registrations in July 1996 than in July last year.
Seat recorded 3,420 registrations compared to 5,522 in July a year ago.
The number of Porsche registrations fell from 643 to 554.
GREEK SOCIALISTS GIVE THE GREEN LIGHT FOR ELECTIONS.
The Greek Socialist Party's Executive Committee has given the green light to Prime Minister Costas Simitis to call snap elections, the party's Secretary General Costas Skandalidis told reporters.
Prime Minister Costas Simitis will make the formal announcement after the cabinet meeting on Thursday, Skandalidis said.
-- Dimitris Kontogiannis, Athens News +301 3311812-4

Israel reduces fears of war with Syria.
Colleen Siegel
JERUSALEM 1996-08-22
Israel's outgoing peace negotiator with Syria said on Thursday that the current tensions between the two countries looked like a storm in a teacup.
Itamar Rabinovich, who as Israel's ambassador in Washington led the failed negotiations with Syria, told Israel Radio that it looks as if Damascus wants to talk rather than fight.
"It seems to me that the Syrian priority {(1)[MISC] is still negotiation.
The Syrians are confused, they are certainly tense, but the general assessment here in Washington is that it is basically a storm in a teacup," he said.
Mr Rabinovic's term as Ambassador is coming to an end.
He will be replaced by Eliahu Ben-Elissar, former Israeli envoy to Egypt and politician of the right-wing Likud party.
On Wednesday, Israel sent a message to Syria via Washington that it is committed to peace and wishes to start negotiations without preconditions.
But it accused Damascus of creating a dangerous climate.
On Wednesday, Syria accused Israel of launching a hysterical campaign against it after Israeli television reported that Damascus had recently test-fired a missile.
It claimed that the purchase of the weapons was for defence purposes.

"The message we have sent (to Syrian President Hafez al-Assad) is that Israel is ready to start peace negotiations at any time and without preconditions," Israeli Foreign Minister David Levy told Israel Radio.
Tensions have risen since Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu took office in June, vowing to hold on to the Golan Heights, which Israel won from Syria in the 1967 Middle East war.
Israeli-Syrian peace talks on the Golan have been deadlocked since 1991, even though the previous government was ready to make concessions on the Golan.
Peace talks between the two sides were last held in February.
"The voices coming out of Damascus are bad, not good.
Media...
are full of expressions and statements that must be worrying...
this artificial atmosphere is very dangerous because those who spread it can become its prisoners," said Levy.
"We expect Syria to respond to the Israeli message to start peace negotiations if it is peace-oriented, because that is our goal," he said. "
We do not want war, God forbid.
Wars benefit no one. "
Israel's Channel Two television said Damascus had sent a "reassuring signal" to Israel.
It did not cite the source of the report.
Netanyahu's and Levy's spokespersons said they could not confirm this.
The television also said that Netanyahu had sent messages through Cairo, the United States and Moscow to calm Syria.
A Polish diplomat denies that the nurses are stranded in Libya.

On Thursday, a Polish diplomat denied a report in a Polish tabloid this week that Libya was refusing exit visas to 100 Polish nurses who wanted to return home after working in the North African country.
"That's not true.

To date, we have not heard of any nurse remaining in Libya involuntarily and we have not received any complaints," Tadeusz Awdankiewicz, Chargé d'Affaires at the Polish embassy in Tripoli, told Reuters by telephone.

The Polish labour ministry announced this week that it would send a team to Libya to investigate, and Awdankiewicz said the investigation was triggered by complaints from some nurses about working conditions, such as non-payment of wages.
He said that there are around 800 Polish nurses working in Libya.
Two Iranian opposition leaders meet in Baghdad.
Hassan Hafidh
BAGHDAD 1996-08-22
An Iranian exile group based in Iraq pledged on Thursday to support Iranian Kurdish rebels after they were attacked by Iranian troops deep inside Iraq last month.

A statement by the Mujahedin Khalq said that its leader Massoud Rajavi met with the Secretary General of the Kurdistan Democratic Party of Iran (KDPI), Hassan Rastegar, in Baghdad on Wednesday and expressed support for the rebellious Kurds in Iran.
"Rajavi stressed that the Iranian resistance will continue to stand by its Kurdish compatriots and the resistance movement in Iranian Kurdistan," he said.
A spokesman for the group said the meeting "marks a new level of cooperation between Mujahedin Khalq and Iran's Kurdish opposition".
In July, Iran heavily bombed targets in northern Iraq to pursue KDPI guerrillas based in areas of Iraqi Kurdish territory outside the control of the government in Baghdad.
The areas of Iraqi Kurdish territory bordering Iran are under the control of guerrillas from the Iraqi Kurdish group, the Patriotic Union of Kurdistan (PUK).
The PUK and the Kurdistan Democratic Party (KDP), Iraq's two main Kurdish factions, have controlled northern Iraq since Iraqi forces were driven out of Kuwait in the 1991 Gulf War.
Fighting between the two sides erupted over the weekend, the worst since the US-sponsored ceasefire last year.
Mujahedin Khalq said that Iranian troops had also shelled KDP positions in the Qasri region of Suleimaniyah province, near the border with Iran, over the past two days.
Around 100 Iraqi Kurds were killed or wounded in the attack.
Iran and Turkey launch air and ground attacks against targets in northern Iraq as they pursue their Kurdish rebels.
US-led air forces in southern Turkey protect Iraqi Kurds from possible attacks by troops from Baghdad.
The Saudi rial is stable in quiet summer trading.
The spot Saudi riyal against the dollar and the riyal's interbank deposit rates were mostly stable this week in quiet summer trading, traders in the kingdom said.
"Saudi Riyal exchange rates have not changed.
The market was very quiet because of the summer holidays," said one trader.
The spot riyal was set at 3.7504/06 to the dollar.
One-month interbank deposits were 5-1/2, 3/8 per cent, three-month 5-5/8, 1/2 per cent and six-month 5-3/4, 5/8 per cent.
One-year funds were six, 5-7/8 per cent.
Israel approves Arafat's flight to the West Bank.
JERUSALEM 1996-08-22

Israel allowed Palestinian President Yasser Arafat to overfly its territory into the West Bank on Thursday, ending a brief crisis between Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organisation, an Arafat adviser said.
"The problem is over.
The President's plane has been cleared to fly over Israeli airspace, but the President is not expected to travel to the West Bank until Monday," Nabil Abu Rdainah told Reuters.

Arafat was due to meet former Israeli Prime Minister Shimon Peres in the West Bank city of Ramallah on Thursday, but the meeting was postponed to Gaza after Israel refused to allow the Palestinian leader's helicopters to fly.
Palestinian officials accused right-wing Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of trying to prevent the Ramallah meeting by keeping Arafat on the ground.
Arafat then cancelled a meeting between Israeli and PLO officials on civil matters at the Allenby Bridge crossing between Jordan and the West Bank.
Abu Rdainah said that Arafat had decided not to fly to the West Bank on Thursday, when Israel lifted the ban, because he had a busy schedule in Gaza and would not be free until Monday.
Arafat will meet Peres in Gaza after the no-fly zone.
JERUSALEM 1996-08-22

Yasser Arafat is due to meet Shimon Peres in Gaza on Thursday, after the Palestinians announced that the right-wing Israeli government had banned the Palestinian leader from flying to the West Bank for talks with the former prime minister.

Japanese Finance Minister Wataru Kubo told a press conference on Wednesday that the Bank of Japan's interest rate policy, which is aimed at ensuring economic growth, has not changed following the publication of the central bank's "tankan" survey.
